repnme.cdata!: Mexico - Water, Women and Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Water, Women, and Development
            Project for Mexico was cancelled by request of the Borrower
            in 1991. The Bank originally approved the loan on June 22,
            1989, and the project was to finance water and sanitation
            services and productive activities in the pilot states of
            Queretaro, Hidalgo, and Michoacan. Subsequently, the newly
            elected Mexican Government implemented a poverty alleviation
            program that made Bank funds unattractive for the
            beneficiary states. The Borrower and Bank considered several
            alternatives to reformulate the project according to the new
            policies. The original effectiveness date of December 27,
            1989 was extended eleven times. Ultimately, the
            reformulation efforts led to the conclusion that it was more
            efficient to terminate the loan and identify a possible new
            operation. The effectiveness date of April 26, 1991 was
            allowed to elapse and all obligations of the parties were
            terminated. This report finds the decision to terminate to
            be prudent and reasonable. The project was well designed and
            took a comprehensive approach to attack the vicious cycle of
            women's lack of productivity. Its conceptual
            underpinnings were accepted by the new Government and
            adopted for the ongoing Women in Solidarity programs. The
            Bank arguably played a valuable role and acted as a
            catalyzer of the actions that followed. Cost recovery was an
            important policy issue involved. The Water, Women, and
            Development Project included a credit line for more
            ambitious activities requiring greater capital expenditures,
            while the Government's approach utilized quasi-grant
            funds requiring limited investments. Such alternate schemes
            might be considered in the context of a new loan operation.

repnme.cdata!: Mexico - Water, Women and Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the project is to
            improve the living standard of low income population groups.
            To that end, the project will include three major components
            relating to: (i) water supply and sanitation; (ii) income
            generating activities; and (iii) project preparation in
            other states. The water and sanitation component comprises a
            line of credit for: (a) installation of water supply and
            sanitation services in about 200 low income communities; (b)
            maintenance of water systems; and (c) technical assistance
            to strengthen the State Water Agencies (SWA), train staff in
            community mobilization techniques, and to implement a health
            education program. The income generating component
            comprises: (a) a line of credit through BANOBRAS to
            financial institutions (FI) in the participating states to
            support the investment and working capital needed by
            beneficiaries to start productive activities; and (b)
            technical assistance to the agency in each state in charge
            of project promotion at the community level. The final
            component for project preparation in other states will
            finance technical assistance to other states for: (a)
            identifying water-cum-productuve activities projects; and
            (b) preparing subprojects for future financing. It will also
            finance priority works in other states.
